content: If there are no entries in Saved Passwords, you would be prompted for one when TB connects to the mail server, such as when TB is restarted. At that point, check the box in the prompt to have the password saved. That is, unless passwords are managed by an external app of the kind that is part of some security suites.

content:
I've attempted to change settings and I'm thinking that possibly I've screwed it all up.

What settings did you attempt to change and why?

I've changed the passwords through Comcast a few times

Why would you want to change passwords multiple times?

Can you login to your account via webmail?

I have constant problems signing in with the same old password so I've contacted Comcast to change the passwords.

It doesn't work that way. Comcast cannot change the password for you. Only you can set the password on the server.

Is there anywhere on Thunderbird where I can check to see what passwords are still listed for me?

All you can do is to tell Thunderbird to remember the password you set on the server, so that you don't get prompted for the password in Thunderbird again and again. You cannot change the account password via Thunderbird though.

To check which passwords Thunderbird has remembered: At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ‚â° > Settings > Privacy & Security > Saved Passwords > Show Passwords

You may want to delete old (and now obsolete) passwords Thunderbird has remembered.

Also, please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ‚â°, then select Help > More Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.
creator: christ1

content:
FRom the 'Menu Bar' toolbar: 'View' > 'Message Body As' Offers 3 options - Original html, Simple html and Plain Text

You can use those options to swap the view of email.

But at this moment - what options have you got selected on each computer?

Plain text does not contain formatting because they are plain text. So if the email used a table to format the positioning of content, then in Plain Text mode that 'table' formatting would be removed. But if bullets were used in a html then they should still display in plain text mode.

Currently, I do not know what is contained in the source. Can you offer some info?

Check if email has been sent with both plain text and html. Select email so it displays in Message Pane In the headers area - Click on 'More' and click on 'View Source' It opens in a new window. Look for these lines:

  • Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"
  • Content-Type: text/html; charset="UTF-8"

If contents only have the text/plain option then email was only sent as plain text. If it has both then email was composed using html, but it's likely you are viewing it in Plain Text mode.

What do you see in the source?

Providing there isn't anything too sensitive - it would be handy to post images of what you see.

Then I'll know what settings you currently use, what info is in view source and the image showing results.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: De tekst in de gele banner "We zullen u nooit vragen een telefoonnummer te bellen, er een sms naar te sturen of persoonlijke gegevens te delen" is een waarschuwing voor scams die voor kunnen komen door het gebruik van een forum, dit heeft niets te maken met het het donatieformulier. Daar is nu eenmaal bepaalde minimale informatie voor nodig: "We begrijpen dat uw privacy zeer belangrijk is. Daarom vragen we om een minimale hoeveelheid aan gegevens die nodig zijn om donaties te verwerken, waaronder factureringsadressen. Om frauduleuze betalingen te voorkomen, gebruiken we adressen in ons interne beoordelingsproces. Uw gegevens worden priv√© gehouden - als u vragen hebt, wend u dan tot ons [https://www.mozilla.org/privacy/websites/ Privacybeleid]. Als u liever niet uw gegevens op ons online donatieformulier invult, kunt u een cheque of geldwissel toesturen."

content:
As you are probably aware - the 'Cards View' is new and constantly under development. So it's inevitable that alterations/modifications to code will occur.

The image shows you are currently using the 'Card View' in version 115.15.0

It would be helpful if you could post the content of your 'userChrome.css' file, so I can copy what you are currently using. Then it's possible to replicate your current state.

If you choose to use 128*: 'Tools' > 'Developer Tools' > 'Developer Toolbox' Alllow connection This can be used to identify the areas which you want to tweak. It can be used to help you modify the 'userChrome.css'.

content:
To confirm the trash folder, I suggest deleting a message and see what happens to it. if it goes to your deleted folder, that is the trash folder. there should be a trash or delete in left sidebar and a right click should offer option to 'empty trash.' After emptying trash, you could do this to verify what folders you have:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformaiton
  2. search for 'profile folder' in left side and then click 'open folder'
  3. exit thunderbird
  4. you are now in profile. click the imapmail folder if imap account or Mail folder if POP. click the account name and the various message folders and their sizes should appear. From here, you can see the sizes of all your folders and if there is a trash folder.
  5. another consideration is to click Tools>clear recent history to ensure cache is clear as you don't want to save that either.
  6. if imap, I also suggest rightclicking accountname in main screen and clicking 'subscribe' to see what folders you are using.
  7. TIP: if imap and if you have multi-megabytes of data, you can delete the message files in windows file explorer when thunderbird is not running to save copying them, as thunderbird will repopulate when restarted.
creator: davidsk

content: In the imapmail folder, any folder there is an imap account. Click it to see its sub folder and then you will see the message folders, such as inbox, sent, etc.

content:
For Cards View, this can be done with css: 

.card-container {     background-color: var(--tag-color) !important; }


To make just the card text have the tag colour: 

.card-container {     color: var(--tag-color) !important; }


Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

video on how to create a css file (Firefox and TB)

content: The colour statement means that whatever colour is defined for the tag will be applied to the text or background. For the Important tag, the default colour is red, so that will be the colour of the text or background. See the attached pictures. You can of course define specific colours for each tagged message, independent of the tag colour.

content: Het lijkt er op dat jullie niet dezelfde installatie/profiel gebruiken van Thunderbird, dus deze staan op 2 aparte pc's, of op 1 pc, maar dan met verschillende profielen. Labels zijn profielafhankelijk en worden niet op de een of andere manier gesynchroniseerd, ook niet via IMAP. Als jullie wel naar dezelfde Postvak IN kijken, dan zou ik zeggen, maak gebruik van aparte submappen met jullie naam waarin de door die persoon te verwerken berichten komen te staan. Als het om 1 pc gaat, dan is het mogelijk om een gezamenlijk profiel te gebruiken op de pc of op een netwerkschijf. Hoe dat werkt met profielen wordt uitgelegd in dit artikel: https://support.mozilla.org/nl/kb/profielbeheerder-thunderbird-profielen-aanmaken-en#thunderbird:win10:tb115.

content: I have no solution, but a comment: messages that have been deleted may still be in the global index. In that case, the search 'finds' the message, but it no longer exists.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanx for the comment, but as I said, the message was not deleted. It was residing in my local archives.
creator: eberger5

content:
Just to let you know, I solved the problem. In looking through some old notes I was reminded that rebuilding the index profile can be helpful. So I deleted global-messages-db.sqlite from my profile while TB was closed. Then I opened TB and let it rebuild the index and now not only is the entry found, but also I can open and view it.

I'm not sure how often rebuilding the index is needed, but it was helpful this time.
creator: eberger5

content: Thank you for sharing that, A good tip to pass along. I had been focused on the global index, but hadn't thought to just delete it. Kewl! :)
creator: davidsk

content:
I think the smtp for the jeffmunk account won't work with OAuth2, since (I think) smtp.bizmail.yahoo.com isn't supported with OAuth2 in TB (imap.mail.yahoo.com is OK). Try changing it to smtp.mail.yahoo.com, which does work with OAuth2, and is consistent with the IMAP server. Remove the entries for the account from Saved Passwords, restart TB, enter the account password in the OAuth2 window. There should be a single oauth:// token in Saved Passwords that works for incoming and outgoing.

If that doesn't work, see this topic about adding the account in Yahoo webmail settings:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1462414
creator: sfhowes

content:
Merci ! Thanks! This worked out perfectly. But I need to tell you a few things. The first and the most important thing to know is that the deleting of the Saved Passwords for the non-working account was the key issue. There were multiples ones saved in there. Once I quit TB and went back in to the troubled account, it forced a new browser window up for me to log into my Turbify Business E-mail account (Yahoo). Once I did that, all my undeleted email showed up in my TB mailbox.

Outgoing mail worked as well but here's the thing to note. imap.mail.yahoo.com worked fine but I waited a bit for it to arrive. Just for the hell of it I also tried imap.bizmail.yahoo.com and that work just as well and maybe arrived a bit faster.

The other 3 account I use with TB are also domain name email account. Two are from another domain and the other one yet another domain. All are hosted by Turbify, all use the imap.bizmail.yahoo.com smtp setting and those 3 work consistently while mine did not. Clearly this was a password issue.

content:
EMMA_SKEPTIC said
Now is there a way to get rid of that useless comma?

That's shown in the above picture: create a pref. intl.date_time.pattern_override.connector_short as a string, give it the value {1} {0} and then restart TB.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thanks again "sfhowes". That works of course, and it a good idea to put the {1} {0} in the right place!

Now everything is perfect!!! Although I don't know if I should reply to messages that are more than one week old . . . (Just kidding)

So why is setting the Date like this important? Of course ymmv, I like to view Inbox with Vertical Layout w/ Message Pane so I can read messages without opening/generating a Tab -- I always have too many Tabs. So getting rid of the System Long Date frees up a lot of space . . . now I think I'll be able to read messages without having to frequently adjust the column widths back and forth --InboxFolders/From/Subject/Date/Message

This is how it looks--a big improvement, although noting that yesterday's time isn't so important just in case someone wants to know. Thanks again to "sfhowes", what a big improvement! Tue 06:44 09/09/24 16:27

creator: davidsk

content:
Yes - I set all those parameters, but I could not get the Outgoing SMTP setup to offer me the Oauth2 choice. I am using Hotmail.co.uk rather than Hotmail.com - perhaps that is a problem.

As others have found the only solution is to delete the Thunderbird Hotmail account (NOT the source Microsoft account) , but not the data. This is deliberately difficult to find. Highlight the account name in the left hand panel and choose 'Account Settings' top right. Bottom left will be 'Account Options' with a drop down arrow. The items below this are NOT the drop down - select 'Account Options' and you get a menu including 'Remove Account', select this and you get the option to remove the account and separately the data - just select 'Remove', do NOT select 'Data'. The effect is instant.

Now re-create the account as you initially did a long time ago - 'Choose what to set up'- 'Email' etc The parameters are automatically set to what you need - apparently just the same as instructed - but something must be different.

If you have a lot of emails (I have several thousand) it takes a very long time to download all the headers - several hours.

I know this is drastic, but you are not modifying the source data, and if you keep your head it works.

content:
I assume you are referring to the last two lines of this two years old discussion https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1391768#answer-1538761

If you do not understand IMAP synchronization, this is not really the forum to gain that understanding. I would refer you to the IMAP standards document for a discussion of the detail of the IMAP protocol and how it is designed to work. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9051/

From that document you will come to understand that any local copy is really nothing more than a cached version of the canonical server version and it could cease to exist at any time. When the local copy is accessed the server is interrogated to determine if the local copy is current and if not it is immediately deleted and a current version is downloaded. This can mean that for those that treat local copies as an archive and delete copies held on the server that suddenly their local mail is deleted to match the server status of the message on the server.

content:
I also experienced extreme performance degradation after upgrading to 128. Deleting a mail or feed item in a folder with 3-10 items freezes Thunderbird for 2 seconds. Deleting a feed item in an RSS folder with 900 items freezes Thunderbird for 30 seconds. Similar size-dependent delay when opening folders. Thunderbird troubleshoot mode seems to reduce the delay by 0-70% (which still means >10s delay for big folders!), but I'm getting very high variance so can't say for sure before more investigation.

@gallium: By chance, does your Thunderbird open a very big mail folder immediately when starting?
creator: honvmpri

content: see https://wiki.mozilla.org/Thunderbird:Testing:Memory_Usage_Problems
creator: wsmwk

content:
It turned out that my issue was 57k mailnews.tags.* entries in prefs.js. I had the option "Automatically create tags from feed category names" turned on in my news feed and it had accumulated a lot of tags over time, saving a config preference for each. After editing prefs.js directly and removing all mailnews.tags.* lines, there are no freezes when opening folders or deleting items.

And to clarify, this worked fine before version 128, so I'd consider it a regression (though some may consider it https://xkcd.com/1172/), but one easily worked around. :)
creator: honvmpri
